intro: Tetragonolobus biflorus var. purpureus, commonly known as the purple-flowered legume, is a herbaceous plant characterized by its distinctive quadrangular stems and clusters of small, purple-pink flowers. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, known for its nitrogen-fixing capabilities through symbiotic bacteria in its root nodules. The leaves are trifoliate, with each leaflet being ovate to elliptic in shape, and the plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it a suitable candidate for ornamental gardening and ecological restoration projects. Its vibrant floral display and ecological benefits make it a valuable addition to diverse plant communities.
